misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays lose alignment when sorting only one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also keep the corresponding names in the same relative order, so that the last name in `names` will match the highest score after `Arrays.sort(scores)`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` rearranges only the `scores` array in-place. The `names` array is a separate array and is not modified, so the association between `names[i]` and `scores[i]` (parallel-array alignment) is broken unless both arrays are permuted together using the same swaps (or the data is stored as objects/pairs and sorted together).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not be the student who actually has the highest score (name-score mismatch).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a parallel array structure will automatically maintain the correspondence between elements in different arrays. Specifically, they think that after calling Arrays.sort(scores), the indices will still correctly map names to their original scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() only sorts the specified array in place and does not affect other arrays. When scores are sorted independently, the names array remains in its original order, breaking the parallel array relationship. The name at index n-1 no longer corresponds to the highest score—it corresponds to whichever student was originally in the last position.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print an incorrect name paired with the highest score. For the sample input, it would print 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)', because Charlie was in position 2 and scores[2]=92 after sorting, but names[2] is still 'Charlie' from the original order.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays were populated together to represent the same entities, the Java execution environment maintains an implicit link between them such that sorting one array will automatically rearrange the other to keep the data pairs intact.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are independent objects in memory with no semantic linkage. The Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the specific array passed as an argument; it has no mechanism to identify or update associated 'parallel' arrays. To sort parallel data, the programmer must either manually implement a sorting algorithm that swaps elements in both arrays simultaneously or group the data into a single object.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned when sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will still match up by index, so the last name (`names[n-1]`) must belong to the highest score (`scores[n-1]`).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` only rearranges the elements inside the `scores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange a separate `names` array to keep the name–score pairing aligned. Parallel arrays require manual synchronized swaps during sorting, or an alternative approach (e.g., sorting indices, or using an array of objects like `Student{name, score}`).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the reported top student name may not correspond to the highest score (name/score mismatch).

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Desynchronization After Single-Array Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort() on the scores array is sufficient to organize all the data, and that the names array will somehow remain synchronized with the scores array after sorting. The student thinks that after sorting scores in ascending order, the element at index n-1 will be both the highest score AND the name of the student with that score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that parallel arrays require parallel manipulation. When you sort only the scores array using Arrays.sort(), you rearrange the scores but leave the names array in its original order. This breaks the index-based correspondence between names and scores. After sorting scores, the name at index i is no longer paired with the score at index i. The student's mental model lacks the understanding that sorting one array in a parallel array structure requires you to apply the same permutation to all parallel arrays to maintain data consistency.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print an incorrect student name paired with the highest score.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
        int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a set of parallel arrays automatically maintains the relationship with elements in the other arrays, or that the association between indices is intrinsic and persistent regardless of mutation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a conceptual convention maintained by the programmer, not a feature of the language. Using Arrays.sort() on one array modifies its elements' positions without any effect on other arrays, effectively breaking the data relationship previously established by the shared index.
